ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: It feels like I actively lost acting skills in this class because we never did any real theatre.
public speaking skills and being able to work with others
The course was great in teaching me valuable skills in collaboration and how creativity can be a habit. I got some insights into the complex experience of what it means to be an artist.
I learned how to step out of my comfort zone and create skits in a collaborative setting.

I gained a great deal of confidence in my ability both as a collaborator and actor through this course, and we worked on refining skills like improvising and managing group dynamics, which will be useful to me regardless of my future career.
Skills in playwriting, acting, and collaboration within theater and in general.
How to do improv, how to collaborate effectively with others and inspire more creativity, and career lessons from experienced people on the theatre-making field
Better understanding of collaboration and theater.

This course taught me a lot about everything that goes into a theatrical production from the scripting, to the importance of the setting, the music, to the performance itself. I gained insight on how to hone my creative abilities both in theater and any other aspect of life. I learned how to better work with others and learn that there was a way for group projects to be enjoyable. The way the course and assignments were set up, each group member had to do their part in a project in order for it to be successful and everyone in the class strived for success.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths -- helps grow confidence in public speaking and acting in front of group, you get to know other classmates well 

Weakness -- don't get to choose groups so sometimes your assignments aren't as good as they could have been
Actually make it a class about acting instead of getting-to-know-you group activities or teaching college kids how to work together.

strengths --> great way to meet friends, if you are shy this is a great class for you to come out of your comfort zone, pretty simple class and not much work
weaknesses --> im not sure if i learned anything new tbh. it was just a fun and chill class which I needed compared to my other very heavy work loaded classes
Strengths: the Professor, the assignments, the morning pages, the class dynamics (and how well you get to know the people in your class)

Strengths: really fun and easy going class. 
Weakness: some of the conversations regarding how we can better collaborate fid drag on a bit longer than it shouldve, but it was overall a fun class.

This course's biggest strength was it's environment, as each session felt less like a class and more like a fun gathering of like-minded people improving one another. If I were forced to find a weakness, the only one I could come up with was that I did not have a chance to work with everyone in class over the semester.

The class itself was something I looked forward to every week, and the readings were always interesting. Our guest speaker was also fantastic. The class dynamic was great, and I really enjoyed getting to know my professor and classmates in a way that is not a feature of most courses.
Strengths - very safe space for breeding creativity by establishing collaboration contracts; Weaknesses - could be slightly more organized in terms of releasing the weeks work
I feel like the journal pages could have been shorter, they were a large time commitment for a course that doesn't give you a writing credit.

The course was ran very well and the structure of the assignments helped us build up to the final project. The first few assignments were about getting to know our classmates while learning the material through different exercises we would do in groups of 2 or 3. This was a really strong way to start off since the midterm and finals required working with others and being comfortable with each other was a huge part of it. Overall a great course and the only improvement I would say could be made was more explanation of the homework assignments the class before to avoid confusion when we arrive at class the next week.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend because it is a great way to get to know other freshman, and the workload isn't too high. It does take up a good amount of time in the week though because you have to meet in small groups outside of every class and also do 3 pages of writing a day.
Not at all if you want a real theatre class. Take it if you want a credit and a class that only meets once a week.

yes if you want a fun and chill and easy class. be cautious that you do need to participate a lot in class and really not be super shy and come out of your comfort zone. great class if you want something creative, work well with others in group projects, and are vocal and active participant.

Absolutely! You get to know a lot of students through the class, the assignments all have a clear intention, and Hal is incredible and gives great advice on what it takes to improve and succeed as an artist.
Yes, if you want a fun, easygoing class.

Absolutely. As a theater studies class, it seems to have some restrictive quality for people not pursuing the major or a similar one, but it truly was a blast and would benefit almost any Yale student.

Definitely! Especially for students interested in theater, but the skills learned are applicable to every field in my opinion, and it perfectly encapsulates the first-year community that first-year seminars are meant to create.
Yes - really pushes you out of your comfort zone and you learn creativity and collaboration skills applicable to success in any field.
Yes I enjoyed the class, but I would want them to be aware that the workload is heavy for a first year seminar. Great environment though!

I would highly recommend this class, especially for students who enjoy theater and wanted to continue in college but are not necessarily theater majors. I think most people with even a slight interest in theater can benefit from this class. It helped me learn to work with other people and taught me social skills as well as creative skills. As well, it gave insight to many aspects of theater that students are often not as much a part of in high school theater such as scriptwriting and designing the characters. This was the most fun class I took all year and I would high recommend it. It didn't even feel like a class at times and I was always excited to do the assignments and show up to class each week. It gave me something to look forward to and that meant a lot.
